---
title: "Electric field within uniform cylindrical charged distribution"
author: Austin Hoover
categories:
  - space charge
draft: true
---

Consider a distribution of infinite line charges charge with density $\lambda(r)$, where $r$ is the radius in the transverse plane. For a uniform-density cylinder of radius $a$, write the charge density as

$$
\lambda(r) = \lambda_0 \left(\frac{r}{a}\right)^2 .
$$

The electric field points in the radial direction. We can calculate the field from Gauss' Law: the electric flux through a cylinder of radius $r$ is proportional to the charge $Q$ enclosed by the cylinder:

$$
\begin{align}
\oint \mathbf{E} \cdot d\mathbf{A} &= \frac{Q}{\epsilon_0} , \\
E_r(r) \cdot 2 \pi r L &= \frac{\lambda(r) L}{\varepsilon_0} , \\
E_r(r) &= \frac{\lambda(r)}{2 \pi \varepsilon_0} .
\end{align}
$$

For the uniform cylinder, this gives

$$
\begin{numcases} {E_r(r)=}
  \frac{\lambda_0}{2 \pi \epsilon_0 a^2}           r, & $r \le a$ \\
  \frac{\lambda_0}{2 \pi \epsilon_0    } \frac{1}{r}, & $r \ge a$
\end{numcases}
$$

Now assume we have a slowly varying longitudinal density $\lambda_0(z)$. At a fixed $z$, we can approximate the transverse distribution as an infinite cylinder with local density $\lambda_0(z). This gives

$$
\begin{numcases} {E_r(r, z)=}
  \frac{\lambda_0(z)}{2 \pi \epsilon_0 a^2}           r, & $r \le a$ \\
  \frac{\lambda_0(z)}{2 \pi \epsilon_0    } \frac{1}{r}, & $r \ge a$
\end{numcases}
$$
